author: Grimms
text: Some men are born to good luck: all they do or try to do comes right-- all that falls to them is so much gain--all their geese are swans--all their cards are trumps--toss them which way you will, they will always, like poor puss, alight upon their legs, and only move on so much the faster.

author: Grimms
text: The world may very likely not always think of them as they think of themselves, but what care they for the world? what can it know about the matter?

author: Grimms
text: One of these lucky beings was neighbour Hans.

author: Grimms
text: Seven long years he had worked hard for his master.

author: Grimms
text: At last he said, "Master, my time is up; I must go home and see my poor mother once more: so pray pay me my wages and let me go."

author: Grimms
text: And the master said, "You have been a faithful and good servant, Hans, so your pay shall be handsome."

author: Grimms
text: Then he gave him a lump of silver as big as his head.

author: Grimms
text: Hans took out his pocket-handkerchief, put the piece of silver into it, threw it over his shoulder, and jogged off on his road homewards.

author: Grimms
text: As he went lazily on, dragging one foot after another, a man came in sight, trotting gaily along on a capital horse.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said Hans aloud, "what a fine thing it is to ride on horseback!

author: Grimms
text: There he sits as easy and happy as if he was at home, in the chair by his fireside; he trips against no stones, saves shoe-leather, and gets on he hardly knows how."

author: Grimms
text: Hans did not speak so softly but the horseman heard it all, and said, "Well, friend, why do you go on foot then?"

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said he, "I have this load to carry: to be sure it is silver, but it is so heavy that I can"t hold up my head, and you must know it hurts my shoulder sadly."

author: Grimms
text: "What do you say of making an exchange?" said the horseman.

author: Grimms
text: "I will give you my horse, and you shall give me the silver; which will save you a great deal of trouble in carrying such a heavy load about with you."

author: Grimms
text: "With all my heart," said Hans: "but as you are so kind to me, I must tell you one thing--you will have a weary task to draw that silver about with you."

author: Grimms
text: However, the horseman got off, took the silver, helped Hans up, gave him the bridle into one hand and the whip into the other, and said, "When you want to go very fast, smack your lips loudly together, and cry "Jip!""

author: Grimms
text: Hans was delighted as he sat on the horse, drew himself up, squared his elbows, turned out his toes, cracked his whip, and rode merrily off, one minute whistling a merry tune, and another singing,

author: Grimms
text: "No care and no sorrow, A fig for the morrow!

author: Grimms
text: We"ll laugh and be merry, Sing neigh down derry!"

author: Grimms
text: After a time he thought he should like to go a little faster, so he smacked his lips and cried "Jip!"

author: Grimms
text: Away went the horse full gallop; and before Hans knew what he was about, he was thrown off, and lay on his back by the road-side.

author: Grimms
text: His horse would have ran off, if a shepherd who was coming by, driving a cow, had not stopped it.

author: Grimms
text: Hans soon came to himself, and got upon his legs again, sadly vexed, and said to the shepherd, "This riding is no joke, when a man has the luck to get upon a beast like this that stumbles and flings him off as if it would break his neck.

author: Grimms
text: However, I"m off now once for all: I like your cow now a great deal better than this smart beast that played me this trick, and has spoiled my best coat, you see, in this puddle; which, by the by, smells not very like a nosegay.

author: Grimms
text: One can walk along at one"s leisure behind that cow--keep good company, and have milk, butter, and cheese, every day, into the bargain.

author: Grimms
text: What would I give to have such a prize!"

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said the shepherd, "if you are so fond of her, I will change my cow for your horse; I like to do good to my neighbours, even though I lose by it myself."

author: Grimms
text: "Done!" said Hans, merrily.

author: Grimms
text: "What a noble heart that good man has!" thought he.

author: Grimms
text: Then the shepherd jumped upon the horse, wished Hans and the cow good morning, and away he rode.

author: Grimms
text: Hans brushed his coat, wiped his face and hands, rested a while, and then drove off his cow quietly, and thought his bargain a very lucky one.

author: Grimms
text: "If I have only a piece of bread (and I certainly shall always be able to get that), I can, whenever I like, eat my butter and cheese with it; and when I am thirsty I can milk my cow and drink the milk: and what can I wish for more?"

author: Grimms
text: When he came to an inn, he halted, ate up all his bread, and gave away his last penny for a glass of beer.

author: Grimms
text: When he had rested himself he set off again, driving his cow towards his mother"s village.

author: Grimms
text: But the heat grew greater as soon as noon came on, till at last, as he found himself on a wide heath that would take him more than an hour to cross, he began to be so hot and parched that his tongue clave to the roof of his mouth.

author: Grimms
text: "I can find a cure for this," thought he; "now I will milk my cow and quench my thirst": so he tied her to the stump of a tree, and held his leathern cap to milk into; but not a drop was to be had.

author: Grimms
text: Who would have thought that this cow, which was to bring him milk and butter and cheese, was all that time utterly dry?

author: Grimms
text: Hans had not thought of looking to that.

author: Grimms
text: While he was trying his luck in milking, and managing the matter very clumsily, the uneasy beast began to think him very troublesome; and at last gave him such a kick on the head as knocked him down; and there he lay a long while senseless.

author: Grimms
text: Luckily a butcher soon came by, driving a pig in a wheelbarrow.

author: Grimms
text: "What is the matter with you, my man?" said the butcher, as he helped him up.

author: Grimms
text: Hans told him what had happened, how he was dry, and wanted to milk his cow, but found the cow was dry too.

author: Grimms
text: Then the butcher gave him a flask of ale, saying, "There, drink and refresh yourself; your cow will give you no milk: don"t you see she is an old beast, good for nothing but the slaughter-house?"

author: Grimms
text: "Alas, alas!" said Hans, "who would have thought it?

author: Grimms
text: What a shame to take my horse, and give me only a dry cow!

author: Grimms
text: If I kill her, what will she be good for?

author: Grimms
text: I hate cow-beef; it is not tender enough for me.

author: Grimms
text: If it were a pig now --like that fat gentleman you are driving along at his ease--one could do something with it; it would at any rate make sausages."

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said the butcher, "I don"t like to say no, when one is asked to do a kind, neighbourly thing.

author: Grimms
text: To please you I will change, and give you my fine fat pig for the cow."

author: Grimms
text: "Heaven reward you for your kindness and self-denial!" said Hans, as he gave the butcher the cow; and taking the pig off the wheel-barrow, drove it away, holding it by the string that was tied to its leg.

author: Grimms
text: So on he jogged, and all seemed now to go right with him: he had met with some misfortunes, to be sure; but he was now well repaid for all.

author: Grimms
text: How could it be otherwise with such a travelling companion as he had at last got?

author: Grimms
text: The next man he met was a countryman carrying a fine white goose.

author: Grimms
text: The countryman stopped to ask what was o"clock; this led to further chat; and Hans told him all his luck, how he had so many good bargains, and how all the world went gay and smiling with him.

author: Grimms
text: The countryman than began to tell his tale, and said he was going to take the goose to a christening.

author: Grimms
text: "Feel," said he, "how heavy it is, and yet it is only eight weeks old.

author: Grimms
text: Whoever roasts and eats it will find plenty of fat upon it, it has lived so well!"

author: Grimms
text: "You"re right," said Hans, as he weighed it in his hand; "but if you talk of fat, my pig is no trifle."

author: Grimms
text: Meantime the countryman began to look grave, and shook his head.

author: Grimms
text: "Hark ye!" said he, "my worthy friend, you seem a good sort of fellow, so I can"t help doing you a kind turn.

author: Grimms
text: Your pig may get you into a scrape.

author: Grimms
text: In the village I just came from, the squire has had a pig stolen out of his sty.

author: Grimms
text: I was dreadfully afraid when I saw you that you had got the squire"s pig.

author: Grimms
text: If you have, and they catch you, it will be a bad job for you.

author: Grimms
text: The least they will do will be to throw you into the horse-pond.

author: Grimms
text: Can you swim?"

author: Grimms
text: Poor Hans was sadly frightened.

author: Grimms
text: "Good man," cried he, "pray get me out of this scrape.

author: Grimms
text: I know nothing of where the pig was either bred or born; but he may have been the squire"s for aught I can tell: you know this country better than I do, take my pig and give me the goose."

author: Grimms
text: "I ought to have something into the bargain," said the countryman; "give a fat goose for a pig, indeed!

author: Grimms
text: "Tis not everyone would do so much for you as that.

author: Grimms
text: However, I will not be hard upon you, as you are in trouble."

author: Grimms
text: Then he took the string in his hand, and drove off the pig by a side path; while Hans went on the way homewards free from care.

author: Grimms
text: "After all," thought he, "that chap is pretty well taken in.

author: Grimms
text: I don"t care whose pig it is, but wherever it came from it has been a very good friend to me.

author: Grimms
text: I have much the best of the bargain.

author: Grimms
text: First there will be a capital roast; then the fat will find me in goose-grease for six months; and then there are all the beautiful white feathers.

author: Grimms
text: I will put them into my pillow, and then I am sure I shall sleep soundly without rocking.

author: Grimms
text: How happy my mother will be!

author: Grimms
text: Talk of a pig, indeed!

author: Grimms
text: Give me a fine fat goose."

author: Grimms
text: As he came to the next village, he saw a scissor-grinder with his wheel, working and singing,

author: Grimms
text: "O"er hill and o"er dale So happy I roam, Work light and live well, All the world is my home; Then who so blythe, so merry as I?"

author: Grimms
text: Hans stood looking on for a while, and at last said, "You must be well off, master grinder! you seem so happy at your work."

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said the other, "mine is a golden trade; a good grinder never puts his hand into his pocket without finding money in it--but where did you get that beautiful goose?"

author: Grimms
text: "I did not buy it, I gave a pig for it."

author: Grimms
text: "And where did you get the pig?"

author: Grimms
text: "I gave a cow for it."

author: Grimms
text: "And the cow?"

author: Grimms
text: "I gave a horse for it."

author: Grimms
text: "And the horse?"

author: Grimms
text: "I gave a lump of silver as big as my head for it."

author: Grimms
text: "And the silver?"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh!

author: Grimms
text: I worked hard for that seven long years."

author: Grimms
text: "You have thriven well in the world hitherto," said the grinder, "now if you could find money in your pocket whenever you put your hand in it, your fortune would be made."

author: Grimms
text: "Very true: but how is that to be managed?"

author: Grimms
text: "How?

author: Grimms
text: Why, you must turn grinder like myself," said the other; "you only want a grindstone; the rest will come of itself.

author: Grimms
text: Here is one that is but little the worse for wear: I would not ask more than the value of your goose for it--will you buy?"

author: Grimms
text: "How can you ask?" said Hans; "I should be the happiest man in the world, if I could have money whenever I put my hand in my pocket: what could I want more? there"s the goose."

author: Grimms
text: "Now," said the grinder, as he gave him a common rough stone that lay by his side, "this is a most capital stone; do but work it well enough, and you can make an old nail cut with it."

author: Grimms
text: Hans took the stone, and went his way with a light heart: his eyes sparkled for joy, and he said to himself, "Surely I must have been born in a lucky hour; everything I could want or wish for comes of itself.

author: Grimms
text: People are so kind; they seem really to think I do them a favour in letting them make me rich, and giving me good bargains."

author: Grimms
text: Meantime he began to be tired, and hungry too, for he had given away his last penny in his joy at getting the cow.

author: Grimms
text: At last he could go no farther, for the stone tired him sadly: and he dragged himself to the side of a river, that he might take a drink of water, and rest a while.

author: Grimms
text: So he laid the stone carefully by his side on the bank: but, as he stooped down to drink, he forgot it, pushed it a little, and down it rolled, plump into the stream.

author: Grimms
text: For a while he watched it sinking in the deep clear water; then sprang up and danced for joy, and again fell upon his knees and thanked Heaven, with tears in his eyes, for its kindness in taking away his only plague, the ugly heavy stone.

author: Grimms
text: "How happy am I!" cried he; "nobody was ever so lucky as I."

author: Grimms
text: Then up he got with a light heart, free from all his troubles, and walked on till he reached his mother"s house, and told her how very easy the road to good luck was.
